H0.text: The bird's prey species would decrease in number if a species of bird stopped reproducing.

H1.text: The food web that the bird belongs to would collapse if a species of bird stopped reproducing.

H2.text: Trees where these birds build nests would grow taller if a species of bird stopped reproducing.

H3.text: This bird species would eventually disappear from nature if it stopped reproducing.

A4.text: Most simply, any species that cannot survive and reproduce in its environment and cannot move to a new environment where it can do so, dies out and becomes extinct.

A5.text: The extinction of one species' wild population can have knock-on effects, causing further extinctions. These are also called 'chains of extinction'.

A6.text: Coextinction is especially common when a keystone species goes extinct.

A7.text: The Haast's eagle was a predator that became extinct because its food source became extinct.
